articles.title: Muscle hypertrophy in men and women
articles.question: Do men and women experience similar muscle hypertrophy from resistance training?
takeaways: Women and men show similar relative hypertrophy from training
Upper arm muscle increased ~16-23% in both sexes after 16 weeks
Strength gains were significant in both groups
Absolute gains differ, but percentage gains are comparable

articles.title: Sex differences in resistance training: a systematic review and meta-analysis
articles.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
articles.question: Are there sex differences in hypertrophy and strength adaptations to resistance training?

limitations: heterogeneity in training protocols across studies

takeaways: No significant sex difference in hypertrophy (effect size = 0.07)
Females showed larger relative gains in upper-body strength
No significant sex difference in lower-body strength gains
Males and females can follow similar resistance training programs

articles.title: The effects of menstrual cycle phase on exercise performance in eumenorrheic women: a systematic review and meta-analysis
articles.question: Does menstrual cycle phase affect exercise performance in eumenorrheic women?

limitations: inconsistent phase verification methods across studies

takeaways: Exercise performance may be trivially reduced in early follicular phase
Effect sizes are small and likely not practically significant
Individual response varies; personalized approach recommended
No strong evidence for periodizing training around menstrual cycle

articles.title: Effects of progressive resistance training on growth hormone and testosterone levels in young and elderly subjects
articles.question: How do growth hormone and testosterone respond to resistance training in young vs elderly men?

limitations: sample size not specified in abstract

takeaways: Resistance training induces GH and testosterone release regardless of age
Young subjects show greater hormonal response than elderly
Both acute exercise and chronic training affect hormone levels
Strength gains of 37-39% achieved in both age groups

articles.title: Muscle conditioning and muscle injuries
articles.question: How does muscle conditioning affect injury rates in athletes?
articles.summary: Reviews how muscle and connective tissue adapt to resistance training, resulting in greater tissue mass and increased tensile strength. Proposes periodization as a training model to increase performance while reducing overtraining and injury.
takeaways: Pre-conditioning and in-season muscle conditioning reduce injuries among athletes
Periodization (varying volume, intensity, and exercises) reduces overtraining and injury risk
Muscle and connective tissue adaptations from resistance training increase tensile strength
Load-bearing and resistive training produce protective tissue adaptations

articles.title: Four-year study of weightroom injuries in a national sample of college football teams
articles.journal: National Strength and Conditioning Association Journal
articles.question: How do weight room injury rates compare to injuries during sport participation?
articles.summary: Four-year prospective study using the Athletic Injury Monitoring System (AIMS) to track weight room injuries in college football teams compared to on-field injuries.
takeaways: Weight room injuries accounted for only 1% of time lost compared to football practice injuries
Weight training is substantially safer than contact sport participation
Injury rates from resistance training are very low in supervised settings
Strength training should not be avoided due to injury concerns

articles.title: Role of resistance training in heart disease
articles.question: Is resistance training safe and beneficial for cardiac rehabilitation patients?
articles.summary: Reviews evidence supporting resistance training as part of cardiac rehabilitation programs, demonstrating safety and benefits for patients with heart disease.
takeaways: Resistance training is an accepted part of cardiac rehabilitation since mid-1980s
Studies show safety in Phase II, III, and IV cardiac rehab programs
Resistance training had fewer cardiovascular complications than aerobic training alone
Benefits include improved strength and functional capacity in cardiac patients

articles.title: Youth resistance training: Updated position statement paper from the National Strength and Conditioning Association
articles.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
articles.question: Is resistance training safe and effective for children and adolescents?

limitations: position statement format rather than systematic review

articles.summary: NSCA position statement updating 1996 recommendations on youth resistance training, addressing risks, benefits, and program design for children and adolescents.
takeaways: Youth resistance training is safe and effective with proper supervision and age-appropriate guidelines
Benefits include increased strength, improved motor skills, and enhanced sports performance
Injury risk is low when qualified professionals supervise and proper technique is emphasized
The NSCA supports resistance training for healthy children and adolescents

articles.title: Epidemiology of weight training-related injuries presenting to United States emergency departments, 1990 to 2007
articles.question: What are the epidemiological patterns of weight training injuries in the US?
takeaways: 90.4% of injuries occurred with free weights
65.5% of injuries resulted from weights dropping on the person
Low back and shoulders are most common injury sites
Strains account for 46.1% of injuries
Males, adolescents, and older persons have highest injury rates

articles.title: Shoulder injuries attributed to resistance training: a brief review
articles.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
articles.question: What are the mechanisms and risk factors for shoulder injuries in resistance training?
takeaways: Up to 36% of resistance training injuries occur at the shoulder complex
Biased exercise selection creates joint and muscle imbalances
Rotator cuff and scapular muscles are often neglected
Unfavorable positioning during exercises increases injury risk
Balance pushing and pulling movements to reduce shoulder injury risk

articles.title: The epidemiology of injuries across the weight-training sports
articles.question: What is the injury epidemiology across different weight-training sports?

limitations: heterogeneity in injury definitions across studies

takeaways: Weight-training sports have relatively low injury rates compared to team sports
Shoulder (6-36%), low back, and knee are most common injury sites
Proper technique and progressive loading reduce injury risk
No significant differences in injury rates by age, sex, or bodyweight class

articles.title: Squatting kinematics and kinetics and their application to exercise performance
articles.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
articles.question: What does biomechanical research tell us about squat depth and safety?
articles.summary: Reviews biomechanical literature on squat depth, knee position, and spinal loading. Addresses common concerns about deep squats and knees traveling past toes.
takeaways: Deep squats are safe when performed with proper technique
Quadriceps development is maximized at parallel depth
Hip extensor activation increases with squat depth
No evidence that posterior pelvic tilt (butt wink) increases lumbar injury risk
Knees extending beyond toes is safe and often necessary for proper form

articles.title: Single versus multiple sets in long-term recreational weightlifters
articles.question: Are multiple sets more effective than single sets for recreational weightlifters?
takeaways: One set is nearly as effective as three sets for strength gains
No significant difference in body composition changes between groups
One-set programs remain effective even after a year of training
Recreational lifters can achieve good results with lower training volume

articles.title: Weight training in youth-growth, maturation, and safety: an evidence-based review
articles.question: Does resistance training affect growth and maturation in youth?
takeaways: Supervised resistance training is safe for pre- and early-pubertal youth
No negative impact on growth or maturation with proper supervision
Growth plate injuries are rare with appropriate technique and loads
Low instructor-to-participant ratios are essential for safety

articles.title: High-intensity and resistance training and elite young athletes
articles.question: Is high-intensity resistance training safe for elite young athletes?
takeaways: Resistance training is safe and effective for developing youth strength
No adverse effects when properly supervised with appropriate precautions
Benefits include improved maximal strength, power, and athletic performance
Age-appropriate program design is essential

articles.title: Musculoskeletal injuries caused by weight training: guidelines for prevention
articles.question: What guidelines prevent weight training injuries in youth?
takeaways: Adequate warm-up reduces injury risk
Loss of form when lifting heavy weights increases injury risk
Proper supervision is essential for injury prevention
Progressive loading helps prevent overuse injuries

articles.title: Weight-training injuries in adolescents
articles.journal: American Journal of Diseases of Children
articles.question: What is the incidence and pattern of weight training injuries in adolescent athletes?
takeaways: Strains are the most common injury type (74.1%)
Back is the most common injury site (59.3%)
Proper technique and supervision reduce injury incidence
Most injuries are minor and resolve quickly

articles.title: Can resistance training reduce injuries in youth sports?
articles.question: Can resistance training programs reduce sports injuries in youth athletes?
takeaways: Resistance training can significantly reduce sports-related injuries in adolescents
Preparatory conditioning improves tissue resilience
Proper program design is essential for injury prevention benefits
Additional research needed on optimal protocols

articles.title: Injuries in strength training: review and practical application
articles.question: What is known about injuries across different strength training modalities?
takeaways: Injury incidence ranges from 0.0017-0.0035 per 100 hours to 1.1-7.0 per 1000 hours
Lower back, shoulder, and knee are most frequently injured areas
Strength training is generally safe across modalities
Most weightlifting injuries result in less than 1 day of missed training

articles.title: Low energy availability and relative energy deficiency in sport: a systematic review and meta-analysis
articles.question: How prevalent is low energy availability in athletes and what are its effects?
takeaways: 44.7% of athletes studied had low energy availability
LEA impairs endurance performance, coordination, and concentration
Athletes with LEA have higher risk of bone stress injuries
Both male (49.4%) and female (44.2%) athletes affected

articles.title: A systematic review, meta-analysis and meta-regression of the effect of protein supplementation on resistance training-induced gains in muscle mass and strength in healthy adults
articles.question: Does protein supplementation enhance resistance training adaptations?

methodology.studyType: systematic review with meta-analysis and meta-regression
limitations: heterogeneity in protein sources and timing

takeaways: Protein supplementation increases 1RM strength by 2.49 kg
Fat-free mass gains augmented by 0.30 kg with protein
Benefits plateau at total intake of 1.62 g/kg/day
Increasing age reduces efficacy; training experience increases it

articles.title: Dietary fiber and health outcomes: an umbrella review of systematic reviews and meta-analyses
articles.question: What health outcomes are convincingly associated with dietary fiber intake?
takeaways: Convincing evidence for reduced pancreatic cancer and CVD mortality
Highly suggestive evidence for reduced all-cause mortality and coronary disease
18 meta-analyses covering 298 prospective studies reviewed
Supports recommendations for higher fiber intake

articles.title: The effect of fluid intake following dehydration on subsequent athletic and cognitive performance: a systematic review and meta-analysis
articles.question: Does rehydration after fluid loss improve subsequent performance?
takeaways: Fluid intake benefits strongest for continuous exercise tasks
Greater improvement at elevated environmental temperatures
Benefits increase with longer exercise duration
Dehydration of 2%+ body mass impairs endurance performance

articles.title: Daily steps and all-cause mortality: a meta-analysis of 15 international cohorts
articles.question: How many daily steps are associated with reduced mortality risk?
takeaways: More steps progressively lower mortality risk up to age-specific thresholds
Adults 60+: benefits plateau at 6,000-8,000 steps/day
Adults under 60: benefits continue to 8,000-10,000 steps/day
Highest quartile (10,900 steps) had 40-53% lower mortality vs lowest

articles.title: The impact of sleep interventions on athletic performance: a systematic review
articles.question: Do sleep interventions improve athletic performance?

limitations: risk of bias in included studies

takeaways: Sleep extension and napping most promising interventions
All sleep extension studies showed positive performance impact
Improved reaction time, sprint performance, and sport-specific skills
Sleep extension to 10 hours improved basketball shooting accuracy 9%

articles.title: Changes in perceived recovery status scale following high-volume muscle damaging resistance exercise
articles.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
articles.question: Does perceived recovery status correlate with physiological markers of recovery?
takeaways: PRS declined from 8.6 to 4.2 following high-volume resistance exercise
Inverse relationship between creatine kinase and PRS (r = 0.58)
PRS reflects physiological muscle damage markers
Can be used as practical tool for monitoring recovery status

articles.title: Exercise dosing to retain resistance training adaptations in young and older adults
articles.question: What is the minimum training dose required to maintain resistance training adaptations?
takeaways: Young adults maintained muscle size with 1/9 of original training volume (3 sets/week)
Older adults (60-75) required 1/3 of original volume to maintain gains
Strength was largely preserved even with 1/9 volume in both age groups
Intensity (load) is more critical than volume for maintaining adaptations

articles.title: Maintaining physical performance: the minimal dose of exercise needed to preserve endurance and strength over time
articles.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
articles.question: What is the minimal exercise dose needed to preserve strength and muscle over time?
takeaways: Young adults can maintain strength for 32 weeks with 1 session/week and 1 set/exercise
Older adults need 2 sessions/week and 2-3 sets/exercise to maintain muscle size
Exercise intensity (relative load) is the key variable for maintenance
Large reductions in frequency and volume are tolerable if intensity is preserved

articles.title: Dose-response relationship between weekly resistance training volume and increases in muscle mass: a systematic review and meta-analysis
articles.question: What is the dose-response relationship between weekly training volume and muscle hypertrophy?
takeaways: Graded dose-response: more weekly sets produce greater hypertrophy gains
10+ sets per muscle per week significantly outperforms <5 sets
Each additional set increases effect size by 0.023
Higher volumes benefit both trained and untrained individuals

articles.title: The resistance training dose response: meta-regressions exploring the effects of weekly volume and frequency on muscle hypertrophy and strength gains
articles.question: How do weekly volume and frequency affect hypertrophy and strength gains?
takeaways: Volume shows diminishing returns for both hypertrophy and strength
Diminishing returns are more pronounced for strength than hypertrophy
Frequency has weak effects on hypertrophy but clear benefits for strength
Direct vs indirect set quantification affects dose-response estimates

articles.title: Is there too much of a good thing? Meta-regressions of the effect of per-session volume on hypertrophy and strength
articles.question: What is the optimal per-session training volume for hypertrophy and strength?
takeaways: Point of diminishing returns at ~11 sets per session for hypertrophy
Point of diminishing returns at ~2 direct sets per session for strength
Distributing volume across 2-3 weekly sessions may be more efficient
More than 15 sets per muscle per session provides minimal additional benefit

articles.title: The effect of weight training volume on hormonal output and muscular size and function
articles.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
articles.question: How does training volume affect muscular adaptations in trained individuals?
takeaways: Trained individuals maintained muscle with 3 sets per muscle group per week
Intensity and frequency must be preserved when reducing volume
No significant difference in hormonal response between volume conditions
Low volume sufficient for maintenance but higher volume may optimize growth
